channel.title: Bloomberg Technology

item.title: Deutsche Bank Aims to Launch Crypto Custody Service in 2026
item.description: Deutsche Bank AG plans to launch its digital assets custody service next year and has enlisted crypto exchange Bitpanda’s technology unit to help build the offering, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Arno Schuetze, Anna Irrera

media:content.media:description: A Deutsche Bank AG branch in Germany. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

item.title: Netflix’s Lofty Valuation Has Even Bullish Investors Nervous
item.description: Netflix Inc. investors face a dilemma: Continue to bet on a stock that has delivered best-in-class returns over the past year or reconsider shares that increasingly look like they’re priced for perfection.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Vlastelica

item.title: Blackout, Fire Warnings Flashed From Home Sensors Hours Before Crises
item.description: Leveraging home sensors and AI, Whisker Labs has developed new ways to rapidly track electricity flows to detect grid faults — leaving some power providers trailing
item.dc:creator: Naureen S Malik, Leonardo Nicoletti

media:content.media:description: Ting devices used for testing are seen during at Whisker Labs' corporate offices on February 5, 2025 in Germantown, Maryland. Whisker Labs has developed a device, Ting, that collects data about the power coming into consumer’s homes and can detect arcing both inside the house as well as on the larger grid. Photographer: Pete Kiehart/Pete Kiehart

item.title: Peter Thiel-Backed Fintech Investor Sells $70 Million Stake in Wise
item.description: Valar Ventures, a fintech fund backed by Peter Thiel, sold a nearly £50 million ($68.8 million) stake in Wise Plc, exiting a position it built as one of the international payments firm’s early investors.
item.dc:creator: Charles Capel

media:content.media:description: The Wise Plc logo.

item.title: Senate Removes Tax Bill Provision Limiting State AI Regulation
item.description: The Senate killed a controversial effort to prevent US states from regulating artificial intelligence, delivering a win for critics of the biggest tech companies after a compromise proposal collapsed.
item.dc:creator: Emily Birnbaum, Oma Seddiq, Steven T. Dennis

media:content.media:description: Tennessee Senator Marsha Blackburn at the US Capitol on June 30. Photographer: Francis Chung/Politico/AP Photo

item.title: SAP Wins Early US Court Decision in Celonis Antitrust Case
item.description: SAP SE won an early round in a lawsuit filed in the US by one of Europe’s most valuable startups accusing the German technology giant of illegally wielding its market power.
item.dc:creator: Christina Kyriasoglou

media:content.media:description: The SAP SE campus in Walldorf, Germany. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

item.title: Chip-Design Firm SkyeChip Is Close to a Malaysian IPO, CEO Says
item.description: Malaysian semiconductor designer SkyeChip Sdn. is “close” to an initial public offering after posting consecutive years of revenue and profit growth, said Chief Executive Officer Fong Swee Kiang.
item.dc:creator: Ram Anand

media:content.media:description: Silicon wafer.

item.title: Korea Wealth Fund to Boost Bets on AI Startups, Eyes China Tech
item.description: South Korea’s sovereign wealth fund plans to increase allocations to tech startups and venture capital funds as part of its broader push to deepen exposure to artificial intelligence and other disruptive technologies.
item.dc:creator: David Ingles, Yoolim Lee

item.title: Insurance Firm Accelerant Files for IPO, Disclosing Rising Sales
item.description: Accelerant Holdings filed for an initial public offering, joining a rush of insurance-related listings in the US.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Hughes

media:content.media:description: The New York Stock Exchange Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

item.title: Struggling Semiconductor Firm Wolfspeed Files for Bankruptcy
item.description: Wolfspeed Inc., a chipmaker caught in President Donald Trump’s push to reshape Biden-era tech subsidies, filed bankruptcy to enact a creditor-backed plan to slash $4.6 billion in debt.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Randles, Steven Church

media:content.media:description: A Wolfspeed wafer Photographer: Boris Roessler/picture alliance/Getty Images

item.title: A Trio of US Treasury Hacks Exposes a Pattern Making Banks Nervous
item.description: In three major hacks, Treasury didn’t deploy cybersecurity measures that could have prevented the attacks or flagged the intruders sooner, a Bloomberg News investigation found.
item.dc:creator: Jordan Robertson, Hannah Levitt, Jake Bleiberg, Jason Leopold

item.title: Apple Weighs Using Anthropic or OpenAI to Power Siri in Major Reversal
item.description: Apple Inc. is considering using artificial intelligence technology from Anthropic PBC or OpenAI to power a new version of Siri, sidelining its own in-house models in a potentially blockbuster move aimed at turning around its flailing AI effort.
item.dc:creator: Mark Gurman

media:content.media:description: Apple Intelligence would rely more heavily on outside technology under a plan being considered by the company.

item.title: Trump Blasts AT&T for Poor Network Performance During Call
item.description: US President Donald Trump blasted AT&T Inc. for poor network performance during a conference call he was holding with faith leaders on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Molly Schuetz, Kelcee Griffis

media:content.media:description: An AT&T store in New York

item.title: Microsoft’s Sales Chief to Take Sabbatical With Layoffs Looming
item.description: Microsoft Corp.’s top sales executive is planning to take a two-month sabbatical, a move that coincides with an expected wave of terminations targeting his organization.
item.dc:creator: Brody Ford, Dina Bass

media:content.media:description: Judson Althoff, executive vice president of Worldwide Commercial Business at Microsoft Corp., speaks during a Bloomberg Technology television interview in San Francisco, California, U.S., on Friday, Jan. 27, 2017. Althoff discussed earnings and cloud computing services.

item.title: Apple Loses Bid to Dismiss Justice Department Antitrust Suit
item.description: Apple Inc. lost its bid to throw out an antitrust case brought by the US Justice Department and a group of state attorneys general on Monday, a victory for the aggressive posture taken during the Biden administration and carried on by enforcers under President Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Josh Sisco

media:content.media:description: An Apple store in Walnut Creek, California.

item.title: Robinhood CEO Sees Crypto, Traditional Finance Merging
item.description: Robinhood CEO and co-founder Vlad Tenev says he expects crypto and traditional finance merging and announces the company is expanding into the EU on “Bloomberg The Close.”

item.title: Trump Says TikTok Buyer Group Found | Bloomberg Tech 6/30/2025
item.description: Bloomberg’s Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow discuss President Donald Trump’s claim that he has found a buyer group for TikTok. Plus, Canada withdraws its digital services tax in a move to restart trade talks with the US. And Elon Musk slammed the US Senate's version of President Donald Trump's spending bill for removing electric vehicle tax credits. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Mexican Fintech Klar Raises $190 Million at $800 Million Valuation
item.description: Mexican fintech Klar said it has raised $190 million through a Series C funding round, led by US private equity firm General Atlantic, that valued the company at more than $800 million.
item.dc:creator: Valentine Hilaire, Maria Clara Cobo

media:content.media:description: Stefan Moller Source: Klar

item.title: Paramount, Trump Confirm Settlement Talks, Delay Court Case
item.description: Paramount Global is in advanced talks to settle a lawsuit filed by US President Donald Trump that alleges the company’s CBS network deceptively edited a 60 Minutes interview with then-Vice President Kamala Harris.
item.dc:creator: Rob Golum

media:content.media:description: The Paramount Studios in Los Angeles.

item.title: Trump’s TikTok Buyer Is the Same Group Behind a Previous Stalled Bid
item.description: The prospective buyer of TikTok’s American operations cited by President Donald Trump is the same investor consortium including Oracle Corp., Blackstone Inc. and venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz, whose bid for the app had stalled amid US-China trade tensions, according to a person familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai, Hadriana Lowenkron

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump during a news conference in the James S. Brady Press Briefing Room of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, June 27, 2025. Trump says the US has made a trade deal with "probably four or five different countries," naming agreements with China and the UK.

item.title: Musk’s X Hires Entrepreneur Nikita Bier as Head of Product
item.description: Elon Musk’s X has hired entrepreneur Nikita Bier as the platform’s new head of product, giving Bier a senior role atop one of the most widely used social apps in the world.
item.dc:creator: Kurt Wagner

media:content.media:description: Nikita Bier

item.title: Zuckerberg Debuts Meta ‘Superintelligence’ Group, More Hires
item.description: Meta Platforms Inc. Chief Executive Officer Mark Zuckerberg announced a major restructuring of the company’s artificial intelligence group, including a commitment to developing AI “superintelligence,” or systems that can complete tasks as well as or even better than humans.
item.dc:creator: Kurt Wagner

media:content.media:description: CEO of Meta Platforms Mark Zuckerberg

item.title: DailyPay Sells Bonds Tied to Fees on Wages That Workers Tap Instantly
item.description: Fintech company DailyPay Inc. this month sold $200 million in bonds backed by fees tied to the company’s main service, an app that lets workers access pay as soon as they’ve earned it rather than wait for paychecks.
item.dc:creator: Scott Carpenter

media:content.media:description: DailyPay is part of a broader group of companies looking to cater to workers who may struggle with access to cash between paychecks.

item.title: US Charges North Koreans in Plot to Dupe More Than 100 Firms
item.description: The US Justice Department announced one arrest and charges against nine more people in connection with an alleged scheme in which North Koreans posed as American tech workers to gain lucrative jobs and fund the country’s government.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Howell O'Neill

media:content.media:description: Kim Il Sung square in Pyongyang, North Korea in 2018.

item.title: Legal Software Startup Clio to Acquire VLex for $1 Billion
item.description: Canadian software company Themis Solutions Inc. struck a deal to buy legal data and research company vLex LLC for $1 billion in cash and shares.
item.dc:creator: Chaimae Chouiekh

media:content.media:description: A general view of a courtroom at Manhattan Criminal Court in New York City.

item.title: International Criminal Court Says It’s Contained Cyber Incident
item.description: The International Criminal Court contained a “sophisticated and targeted” cybersecurity incident that it first identified last week, the organization said in a statement Monday.
item.dc:creator: Cameron Fozi

media:content.media:description: The International Criminal Court headquarters in The Hague.

item.title: UK Stands by Digital Tax After Canada Bows to Trump Pressure
item.description: The UK is currently planning to keep its digital services tax, a person familiar with the matter said, after Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney scrapped their own levy to restart trade talks with President Donald Trump’s administration.
item.dc:creator: Joe Mayes

item.title: Audacy and iHeart Sign Program-Distribution Deal to Compete With Spotify
item.description: Audacy Inc. and iHeartMedia Inc., the two largest US radio broadcasters, are teaming up in a program distribution deal designed to reach more listeners and better compete with streaming leader Spotify Technology SA.
item.dc:creator: Rob Golum

media:content.media:description: The iHeartMedia Inc. application is seen in the App Store on an Apple Inc. iPhone in Washington, D.C., U.S., on Thursday, March 1, 2018. Embattled iHeartMedia is circulating documents for a bankruptcy filing that could come as soon as this weekend for the biggest U.S. radio broadcaster.

item.title: Oracle Inks Cloud Deal Worth $30 Billion a Year
item.description: Oracle Corp. said it has signed a single cloud deal worth $30 billion in annual revenue — more than the current size of its entire cloud infrastructure business.
item.dc:creator: Brody Ford

media:content.media:description: Oracle Corp. campus in Redwood City, California.

item.title: Morgan Stanley Reshuffles Tech Investment Banking Leadership
item.description: Morgan Stanley has appointed Drew Guevara as a global co-head of technology investment banking as part of a broader reshuffle of one of the Wall Street bank’s most storied franchises.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Gould

media:content.media:description: The Morgan Stanley headquarters in New York.
